did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.physdesc: Correspondence, reports, photographs, plans, statistical data, notes, scientific papers, speeches, radio talks, articles, photographs, minutes, and other papers.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Papers include correspondence, reports, photographs, plans, statistical data, notes, and scientific papers pertaining mainly to the work done in China and Thailand and at Cornell by Professor Love, a specialist in cereal breeding and the application of statistical methods to agricultural research; papers concerning China relate mainly to agricultural research, extension work, and reconstruction at the University of Nanking, the needs and problems of that university, particularly during the Japanese occupation, the studies of Nanking graduate students at Cornell, the field work and studies of Chinese trainees at Cornell and in American industry, and assistance Love gave to Chinese agronomists; also, speeches, radio talks, articles, and various papers, including the manuscript of "The Cornell-Nanking Story" by Love and John H. Reisner.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Harry H. Love was a professor of Plant Breeding at Cornell University; department chairman, 1944-1949; special consultant in plant breeding, University of Nanking, 1925, 1929; advisor in agriculture and crop improvement to the Chinese Ministry of Industries and special lecturer at the University of Nanking and the Central University, 1931-1934; advisor at the agricultural experiment station, University of Puerto Rico, Rio Piedras, 1939, 1940; member of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction of China, 1949-1950; and advisor in rice breeding, Thailand, 1950-1956.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Papers include correspondence, reports, photographs, plans, statistical data, notes, and scientific papers pertaining mainly to the work done in China and Thailand and at Cornell by Professor Love, a specialist in cereal breeding and the application of statistical methods to agricultural research; papers concerning China relate mainly to agricultural research, extension work, and reconstruction at the University of Nanking, the needs and problems of that university, particularly during the Japanese occupation, the studies of Nanking graduate students at Cornell, the field work and studies of Chinese trainees at Cornell and in American industry, and assistance Love gave to Chinese agronomists; also, speeches, radio talks, articles, and various papers, including the manuscript of "The Cornell-Nanking Story" by Love and John H. Reisner; and photographs and printed matter; also, correspondence, minutes, and reports relating to organizations in which Love participated, among them Rotary International, Agricultural Missions, Inc., the Advisory Committee for Foreign Students at Cornell, the Cosmopolitan Club at Cornell, the Ithaca Presbyterian Church, the American Society of Agronomy, Sigma Xi, and Tau Kappa Epsilon fraternity, as Cornell chapter advisor and chairman (1934-1935) of its court of inquiry.

Love's correspondence (1926-1949) contains numerous references to the military and political situation in China, in particular the looting of Nanking in 1927, the Japanese bombing of that city and its fall in 1937, the plight of refugees during World War II, and the rise of the Communists to power; post-war letters comment occasionally on the operation of American economic and technical assistance programs in underdeveloped countries; a few letters are concerned with the missionary work of American Protestants in China, Syria, and Thailand. Also, a two page record of a conversation between Love and Henry Munger regarding the application of statistics to plant breeding, 1962. Correspondents include S. Neale Alter, Sanford Atwood, A. J. Bowen, J. Lossing Buck, Pearl S. Buck, Y. G. Chen, Y. S. Chen, T. H. Chien, Owen L. Dawson, B. A. Garside, Burgoyne L. Griffing, J. B. Griffing, G. Weidman Groff, Raymond S. Hall, Margaret Higgins, Donald C. Kerr, J. R. King, Carl E. Ladd, Kung Ksiang Lin, Walter K. Lowdermilk, Albert R. Mann, Clyde H. Myers, William I. Myers, Jared T. Newman, Bill Pan, Robert L. Pendleton, R. H. Porter, Frank W. Price, Elsie M. Priest, John H. Reisner, George E. Ritchey, Horace W. Ryburn, Knowles A. Ryerson, T. H. Shen, K. S. Sie, Burl Alva Slocum, Louis C. Smythe, Sao-ke Alfred Sze, P. W. Tsou, and Roy W. Wiggans.

controlaccess.head: Names:
controlaccess.corpname: Cornell University.Advisory Committee for Foreign Students.

prefercite.head: Cite As:
prefercite.p: Harry H. Love papers, #21-28-890. Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library.

did.unittitle: Agricultural Education Foundation (correspd.) with Felton Bristol, Reisner 1928-1929.
Correspondence -B- Bowen, A. J. (President, University of Nanking), 1925-1935.
Advance of Southern forces; no confidence in Northern soldiers.
Written on board U.S. gunboat, re: looting and disorders. 4 pp. mimeo.
One long letter to Dr. Bowen from Elsie Priest [q.v.] , concerning staff and program; encl. in Bowen to Love, Nov. 24.
Correspondence Buck, Dr. J. Lossing and Buck, Pearl S., 1927-1947.
8 pp. typed carbon re: events in Nanking in Mar.; written from Unzen, Japan. Signed by Pearl Buck. Southern troops said to be the looters.
Some explanation for behavior of troops (left wing of Kuomintang); written from Unzen. From JLB
ALS from Pearl Buck; written from near Kobe.
Caldwell, Oliver J. (field representative, U. of Nanking, New York City office), 1937-1940.
Mimeo of cablegram received through the Department of State re: bombing of West China Campus.

Informal report (poor carbon) of conference held in Nanking to discuss the proposed North China Agricultural Institute; submitted by Elsie M. Priest; * 5 pp. letter re: same, from Chen to HHL. (Miss Priest was Treasurer of the Chengtu branch of Shantung Christian University in 1947; see letterhead of letter of 1/22/47 in Box 1, #2609.)
Report on political situation; student radicalism - northern schools problem of land registration, incl. Univ. property - new law.
Letter reporting on first bombing of Nanking by Japanese planes; bombing of Sept. 19; question of moving the University - morale.
Refers back to fall of Nanking in Dec. 1937; work maintained at West China Union University at Chengtu.
Return to Nanking campus from Chengtu.
Last letter; city quiet "since Liberation Day"; religious activities continue as usual.

scopecontent.p: 1929, report on cotton improvement studies at U. of Nanking. Scattered comments on political and military situation; problems of flood and drought; some from Peiping, 1939. Nanking, 1944; working in import-export, Shanghai, 1946-1950.

did.unittitle: Chien, T. H. (Vice-Director of National Ag. Research Bureau, Nanking), 1929-1938.

scopecontent.p: Mainly agricultural research, but letter of Sept. 4, 1937 refers to Japanese bombing.

did.unittitle: Chinese Embassy, Hu-shih, Washington, B. C. 1942. Routine requests, ans. by secretary.
China Institute in America. New York 1939-1946.
Dawson, Owen L. Shanghai, China. 1936-1942. Letter referring to situation Shanghai, Feb. 26, 1938.
Garside, B. A. (Secretary-Treasurer, China Union University), 1929-1941.

scopecontent.p: Mainly administrative correspondence. N. b. July 25, 1936, 3 pp. letter re: particular problems to be encountered at Cheeloo because of the "notorious" conservatism of Shantung province.

did.unittitle: Groff, G. W. (Professor of Horticulture), Canton, China, 1935-1943.

4 pp. printed letter to his friends from G. W. G., Lingnan Univ., Canton, China, reporting on the state of work; refugee conditions. File is mainly professional correspondence on horticultural subjects.
Typed carbon of letter from Tientsin, re: Japanese occupation.

scopecontent.p: Considerable comment on staff members and various situations at U. of N. in fall of 1934 and 1935, including mention of the Bucks.

did.unittitle: Enclosing clipping re execution of Feng Jui [Rui?], CU Ph. D. in Canton, Sept. 9th, for "corruption. "
Newsletter giving details of events from time of first air raid, Sunday, Aug. 15th, 6 pp. typescript. Very interesting; written after arrival in Seattle on Sept. 22nd.
Ku, Shih, Peiping, China, 1935-1938. CC's of HHL's letters; one calling card and printed notice from Hu Shih.

Newsletter apparently typed in US from an original which had been snipped here and there by censors; written from National Szechuan University, Chengtu, re: refugee problems, development of China into a democratic nation, which he thinks "inevitable"; U. S. air and ground troops in Chengtu; Chinese students' views of Americans.
Marriage, surrender of Japan. Mimeo newsletter.
Return to Lingnan University in Canton.; inflation; fighting between Nationalists and Communists.
Lowdermilk, Walter Clay (Forest Research, U. of Nanking), 1925-1942.

scopecontent.p: Carbon of memorandum on erosion, runoff and vegetative cover conditions of the Hwai, Yi, and Shu River watersheds (Dec. 11, 1925). Typescript of study on the consequences of deforestation and slope cultivation. Later correspondence re: runoff studies. (WCL at Berkeley and Chief of Division of Research, Soil Conservation Service, USDA.)

did.unittitle: Ministry of Finance; Ministry of Industry 1934.

scopecontent.p: Chinese language newspaper; typescript carbon copy of speech by Kiang [apparently Chiang Kai-Shek] at Nanching (Mar. 14, 1927).

did.unittitle: Myers, Clyde H. Jan.-May 1926. (Mainly carbons of HHL's letters to M.)
Description of voyage from Marseilles to Shanghai; meets tea and rubber planters from India, Java, Penang, Borneo.
First impressions on arrival at Shanghai and Nanking.

5 pp. mimeo Christmas letter from Frank W. Price and family, concerning various experiences during that year; revisit to Nanking - war devastation; journey from Shanghai to Chengtu in hinterland by steamer, train, and truck; migrations westward; air raids at Chungking; refugee aid, inoculation against cholera; wife's part of letter very full and colorful on truck ride from Kunming to Chengtu.
Mimeo letter written from Shanghai after Communists came to power; have decided to stay on. (1 p. )
Pen, S. C. Letter & article, 1937, re: rice yields.
Porter, R. H. 1925-Feb. 1927. Wheat and millet smut.

scopecontent.p: On political and military situation in China (Dec. 28, 1926; Mar. 10, Apr. 9 [n.b., 8 pp.], and May 31, 1927); work in Paraguay (1946, 1948).

did.unittitle: Priest, Miss Elsie H. (see above, Folder 16), Nanking, China 1927-1930.
Priest, Miss Elsie M. (see above, Folder 16), China 1931-1943.

Encl. Reisner's letter re: Outerbridge. Cf. Reisner folder below. Mimeo memorandum of J. L. Buck [q. v. ] on trip of Nanking faculty representative to North China in interest of furthering cooperation on agricultural projects.
Carbon copy of letter from Reisner to Albert R. Mann re: developments in China since 1911.
To "dear friends" and to HHL re: ejection from Nanking
Newsletter from Sierra Leone on African missions.
Ritchey, G[eorge] E. Nov. 1925-Mar. 1926. Agronomy Dept., Nanking U., personal career plans and planting breeding.

Sie, Dean K.S., Dean of College of Agriculture, and Forestry, Nanking, 1930; Director, National Agricultural Research Bureau, Ministry of Industry, Shanghai, 1936. Mainly professional; mentions move to Chungking in 1938. With UNRRA in Washington, 1945.
Slocum, Mr. & Mrs. Burl Alva (B.A. Slocum [CU '27-'28, '29, '30-'32 Grad] was an economic entomologist at U. of Nanking), 1934-1940.
Some comment on the (J. Lossing and Pearl) Buck Family and other members of the Nanking community.
Written from Chengtu, on Japanese raids on Chungking and Chengtu; concern about French Indo-China being cut off and future of the Burma route.
Mimeo Christmas letter; attempt to establish a "safety" zone in the area.

3 pp. purple ditto letter from Nanking, reporting on student demonstrations, Communist agitation; [Nationalist] government bans on demonstrations, and secret police action; political discussions having been stilled earlier, students ripe for first agitator; tendency of Church to stress "personal piety and have little concern with the stirring issues of the day."
Steward, Dr. & Mrs. An. N., Nanking, China 1925-1940 (+photos)
Thorp, James, Peiping, China 1934-1936. (Chief Soil Technologist with the National Geological Survey of China)

Tsou, P. W. (CU grad, Dean of National SE University in Nanking; Ministry of Industry, Commerce and Labor, Shanghai, 1931; Cotton Industry Commission of National Economic Council, Shanghai, 1935; 1943+, Chungking and then rep. to UN Interim Commission on Food and Agriculture), 1925-1937.
On Japanese invasion of China. Various dates, reports on agricultural needs of China.
Wiggans, R. G. Feb. 1927-May 1930 [Roy Glen Wiggans, CU, MS Agr. '1 Ph.D. '19]
Wiggans, R. G. June 1930-Sept. 1930 + N. D.
Williams, J. E., Nanking, China, 1924-1926 [John Elias Williams, 1871-1927; see DAB.]
Yu, Tang Siang, University of Hanking, Hanking, China 1934-1935.
Materials Purchased and sent to China Mar. 1932-Feb. 1934.
Materials Purchased and sent to China Mar. 1934-May 1937.
Graduate School: Residence and Language Requirements 1941-1948.
Graduate School: Lists of Degrees, Scholarships, Exams; Admissions 1941-1944.
Graduate- Students Registered with Dr. Love 1942-1947.

scopecontent.p: Mainly correspondence between Sao-ke Alfred Sze and HHL concerning daughter Julia's financial arrangements while a student at Cornell (Class of 1938) and later in New York City. Sze's letters contain occasional reference to the situation in China - Japanese incursions, severity of living conditions plight of refugees, and the like. Nb. Folders 59, 60.

scopecontent.p: Agricultural Missions Foundation (or Incorporated) was located at 156 5th Avenue, New York City. Files contain bulletins and newsletters, minutes, reports, and scattered correspondence, 1938-1950.

NOTE: Acc. #21/2/87 (Dean of NYS College of Agriculture Carl E. Ladd) also contains files on the Agricultural Missions Fdn.: Box 5, Folder 11, 1933-1934; Box 12, F. 2, 1936-1937 (Reisner); Box 14, F. 29, 1937-1938; Box 23, F. 50, 1942-1943. Acc. #23/2/749 (NYS College of Home Economics Records) on same: Box 12, F. 20-22, ca. 1930-1945 (Reisner, Merrill Palmer; rosters; curriculum).

Includes student rosters, curriculum information, etc. on the school for missionaries sponsored by the NYS College of Agriculture, 1941 and 1942. Of special interest is a mimeo copy (14 pp. typescript single-space) of a letter, Apr. 11, 1940, from E. A. White, describing a journey he and colleagues made by train, bus, and mule from Rangoon into the mountains of North Burma; contains much comment on travel conditions, missionary activities, the standard of living and customs of the natives, orchids observed on the trail, etc. (Edward Albert White, 1872-1943, of the C. U. Department of Floriculture and Ornamental Horticulture, 1913-1939, and author of American Orchid Culture, 1942.)

Includes a mimeo copy (2 pp. ts.) of a letter to Professor Charles A. Taylor and the Faculty of the School for Missionaries from an alumna, Nina M. Stallings, Chengtu, Szechwan Province, China, Jan. 12, 1943, concerning her work: "All that you have ever heard about this wonderful province is true and improving every season. There is the most unbelievable production in these fields." Mentions that she was in need of goat's milk, but did not know how to milk one; urges that the unit on goat husbandry include learning how.

scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence concerning the unauthorized use of HHL's tables of statistics by a third party (1938-1939).

did.unittitle: Alter, S. Neale, Syria. 1936-1940 & N. D.

scopecontent.p: SNA, a Presbyterian missionary to Syria, concerning need for technical assistance in agriculture among Bedouin peasants; desirable for missionaries to have this type of training, as well as theological studies. Also, a few letters to Mrs. Love from Mrs. Alter re: their life and work, the effect of the coming of World War II, and other matters.

4 pp. typescript from R. W. Wiggans, mainly news of Plant Breeding Department.

From "Dick" (J. R. King), St. Croix, Virgin Islands, concerning controversy between the Office of Experiment Stations and the AAAS re: the proposed publication of an article in the May 22, 1953 issue of Science.
Has just moved to Horticultural Research Center, Louisiana State Univ., Baton Rouge. Letters make references to dissatisfaction with Mutual Security Administration.
6 pp. handwritten letter from Sanford Atwood reporting Cornell Plant Breeding Department news.
From "Larry," Singapore, re: arrival of General William ("Wild Bill") Donovan as ambassador to Thailand.
P. W. Tsou, encl. cc of letter to W. I. Myers re: possible employment opportunities with international organizations; also letter of Dec. 15th.
John L. Mott, NYC. [not John R. Mott]
From "Knowles" (Knowles A. Ryerson), Taipeh; also from American Embassy, Manila, P. I., Nov. 26th.
Also from "Larry", Bakersfield, California, further on M. S. A., Donovan in Thailand; references to R. L. Pendleton of Johns Hopkins.
From Robert L. Pendleton; also, carbons of letters to "Dick" (King?) from R. L. P. and social correspondence of Mrs. Pendleton. (Ref. to Donovan in Dec. 6 letter.)

Royse P. Murphy, Plant Breeding Department news.
From Pendleton in Baltimore. (Feb. 18 letter is cc to Dick, Feb. 19 contains ref. to Knowles.)

Cc of letter from Raymond D. Meade, Director of the A. U. A. Language Center in Bangkok, sending credentials of a Thai police corporal to Michigan State; wishes to study police administration and is being sponsored by the Criminal Investigation Division of the Thai National Police. Also visa request document for student, Mar. 5th.
Further correspondence of R. L. King, at L. S. U., more on F. O. A., - also, carbon copies of letters from HHL at Bangkok to various colleagues concerning positions available in his field.
General correspondence during H. H. Love's stay in Thailand, Apr.-July, 1954.

Letters from Bill Pan, formerly at Cairo, Erwin R. Brooks, Donald C. Kerr (re: Thai police corporal mentioned in Feb. 27, 1954 letter from Meade in Folder 19), Pendleton, King, and others. Also, carbons of HHL ' s letters to Ryerson and other colleagues; and cc's of Pendleton 's letters to third parties.

scopecontent.p: Includes letter, Apr. 29, 1927, from Wiggans, concerning the assault on Nanking by the Revolutionary Army and the killing of Dr. [John Elias] Williams: "We were totally unprepared for the brutal assault that was made on all foreigners in Nanking and for the utter destruction which they wreaked on all personal property."
